body_content.explanation: to cause a weapon to shoot bullets, arrows, or missiles for a second, third, etc. time:
examples: It took, on average, five minutes for the gun crews to reload and refire.
In no case will the gun be re-fired.

body_content.explanation: to start an engine or a machine for a second, third, etc. time, or to start for a second, third, etc. time:
examples: The train runs out of steam every now and again, but generally gets re-fired.
On one occasion, the motor stalled, but quickly refired.

body_content.explanation: to cause someone to have a particular feeling for a second, third, etc. time:
examples: Recent research projects have refired my interest in this subject.
The two goals re-fired her competitive urge.

body_content.explanation: to remove someone from their job for a second, third, etc. time, either because they have done something wrong or badly, or as a way of saving the cost of employing them:
examples: She has reorganised her staff members and even refired some.
He has been hired and fired and re-hired and re-fired numerous times.

body_content.explanation: to heat objects made of clay in a kiln (= a special oven) for a second, third, etc. time:
examples: Grind off the excess enamel and re-fire.
Refired ceramics, collage, and found objects all figure in the show of 21 artists.
